bestBHT.bht: The modified covenant emphasizes the connection between the heart and mind, highlighting the transformative nature of this relationship with God. By deliberately altering the order of heart and mind, the author communicates the profound impact of this covenant. With careful word selection, the lasting significance of this covenant is conveyed, illustrating the profound inner change experienced by believers.

Archibald T. Robertson: The author changes τω οικω Ισραελ (Hebrews 8:10) thus without altering the sense.
He also changes the order of 'heart' (καρδιας) and 'mind' (διανοιαν) from that in Hebrews 8:10.
John Gill: This is the covenant that I will make with them,....

bhtAttempts.bht: This verse in Hebrews, as the commentator notes, is a slight modification of a passage from Jeremiah 31:33. The change in wording emphasizes the connection between the heart and mind in the covenant being made. The author of Hebrews is careful in his selection of words, ensuring that while the order is changed, the true meaning remains intact. Ultimately, this verse highlights the significance of this covenant, indicating a deep transformation that occurs within individuals as they enter into this new relationship with God.

The connection between the heart and mind is emphasized in this covenant, as highlighted by the modifications made from the original source. The intentional change of the order in which heart and mind are mentioned underscores the transformative nature of this relationship with God. The careful selection of words in Hebrews expresses the profound impact of this covenant, demonstrating the significant inner change that believers experience. This modified verse in Hebrews conveys the enduring significance of this covenant with God.

The emphasis on the heart and mind is evident in this modified covenant, reflecting the transformative nature of the relationship with God. By altering the order of heart and mind, the author underscores the profound impact of this covenant. The intentional choice of words in Hebrews highlights the lasting significance of this covenant, illustrating the profound inward change experienced by believers.
